monster.name: Manifestation of Joy

hp.special: half the hit point maximum of its summoner

languages: all languages known to its summoner

trait.name: Private Summons
entries: The manifestation has resistance to any damage dealt by any creature except for the summoner. Any other creature that damages the manifestation summons their own manifestation.

trait.name: Empathic Bond
entries: While the manifestation exists, the summoner is unable to feel joy. The manifestation has full access to the thoughts, feelings, and memories of the summoner. When the manifestation takes damage, the summoner makes a {@dc 14} Wisdom save. On a success, the summoner regains hit points equal to the damage dealt, or half as much on a failed save.

trait.name: Killjoy
entries: When this manifestation is summoned, its summoner loses hit points equal to half of the summoner's hit point maximum. If this would bring the summoner to 0 hit points, it brings them to 1 hit point instead.

trait.name: Late Bloomer
entries: The manifestation's recharge abilities start combat expended, and cannot be used the first round of combat.

trait.name: Smoky Form
entries: The manifestation can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

action.name: Evoke Shame
entries: The manifestation brings forth a joyful memory for the summoner and attempts to bring the summoner shame. The summoner must make a {@dc 14} Intelligence save or take (summoner's hit die) psychic damage. The manifestation loses hit points equal to half of the psychic damage dealt.

action.name: Painful Reintegration {@recharge 5}
entries: The manifestation fuses with the summoner, destroying the manifestation. The summoner must make a {@dc 14} Charisma save. On a success, the summoner regains hit points equal to half the remaining hit points of the manifestation when it was destroyed.

monster.name: Manifestation of Anger

hp.special: half the hit point maximum of its summoner

languages: all languages known to its summoner

trait.name: Private Summons
entries: The manifestation has resistance to any damage dealt by any creature except for the summoner. Any other creature that damages the manifestation summons their own manifestation.

trait.name: Empathic Bond
entries: While the manifestation exists, the summoner is unable to feel anger. The manifestation has full access to the thoughts, feelings, and memories of the summoner.

trait.name: Smoky Form
entries: The manifestation can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

action.name: Evoke Guilt
entries: The manifestation instills empathy those who have been on the receiving end of the summoner's powers. The summoner must make a {@dc 14} Intelligence save or take (summoner's hit die) psychic damage. The manifestation regains hit points equal to half of the psychic damage dealt.

action.name: Wrathful Dagger
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) cold damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) force damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) psychic damage.

action.name: Retributive Flurry {@recharge 5}
entries: The manifestation strikes its summoner up to three times with its wrathful dagger. If any of them hit, the summoner must make a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition frightened}. The saving throw can be repeated at the end of each of the summoner's turns.

reaction.name: Repression
entries: When the summoner takes an action or a bonus action, the manifestation can cause them to make a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the action or bonus action is lost.

monster.name: Manifestation of Trust

hp.special: half the hit point maximum of its summoner

languages: all languages known to its summoner

trait.name: Private Summons
entries: The manifestation has resistance to any damage dealt by any creature except for the summoner. Any other creature that damages the manifestation summons their own manifestation.

trait.name: Empathic Bond
entries: While the manifestation exists, the summoner is unable to feel trust or be {@condition charmed}. The manifestation has full access to the thoughts, feelings, and memories of the summoner. When the manifestation takes damage, the summoner makes a {@dc 14} Wisdom save. On a failed save, the summoner takes psychic damage equal to half the damage dealt to the manifestation.

trait.name: Late Bloomer
entries: The manifestation's recharge abilities start combat expended, and cannot be used the first round of combat.

trait.name: Aura of Isolation
entries: Other creatures within 30 feet of the manifestation cannot readily help one another. When such a creature attempts the help action, or to cast a spell targeting anyone other than itself, the manifestation, or the manifestation's allies, the creature must make a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the attempt fails, the action and any spell points used being lost.

trait.name: Smoky Form
entries: The manifestation can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

action.name: Evoke Doubt
entries: The manifestation nurtures seeds of doubts in the summoner. The summoner must make a {@dc 14} Intelligence save or take (summoner's hit die) psychic damage. The manifestation gains hit points equal to half of the psychic damage dealt.

action.name: Painful Reintegration {@recharge 6}
entries: The manifestation fuses with the summoner, destroying the manifestation. The summoner must make a {@dc 14} Charisma save. The summoner takes psychic damage equal to the remaining hit points of the manifestation when it was destroyed, or half as much on a successful save.

monster.name: Manifestation of Fear

hp.special: half the hit point maximum of its summoner

languages: all languages known to its summoner

trait.name: Private Summons
entries: The manifestation has resistance to any damage dealt by any creature except for the summoner. Any other creature that damages the manifestation summons their own manifestation.

trait.name: Empathic Bond
entries: While the manifestation exists, the summoner is unable to feel fear or be {@condition frightened}. The manifestation has full access to the thoughts, feelings, and memories of the summoner. When the manifestation takes damage, the summoner makes a {@dc 14} Wisdom save. On a failed save, the summoner takes psychic damage equal to half the damage dealt to the manifestation.

trait.name: Late Bloomer
entries: The manifestation's recharge abilities start combat expended, and cannot be used the first round of combat.

trait.name: Despicable Cowardice
entries: Attacks made against the manifestation have advantage.

trait.name: Smoky Form
entries: The manifestation can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

action.name: Painful Reintegration {@recharge 5}
entries: The manifestation fuses with the summoner, destroying the manifestation. The summoner must make a {@dc 14} Charisma save. The summoner takes psychic damage equal to the remaining hit points of the manifestation when it was destroyed, or half as much on a successful save.

reaction.name: Feast on Self-Loathing
entries: As a reaction when the summoner attempts to damage the manifestation with a spell or attack, the manifestation forces the summoner to make a {@dc 14} Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, the manifestation gains resistance to all damage types until the end of its next turn, and gains hit points equal to the summoner's hit die. This healing can bring the manifestation past its initial hit point total.

monster.name: Manifestation of Sadness

hp.special: half the hit point maximum of its summoner

languages: all languages known to its summoner

trait.name: Private Summons
entries: The manifestation has resistance to any damage dealt by any creature except for the summoner. Any other creature that damages the manifestation summons their own manifestation.

trait.name: Empathic Bond
entries: While the manifestation exists, the summoner is unable to feel fear or be {@condition frightened}. The manifestation has full access to the thoughts, feelings, and memories of the summoner. When the manifestation takes damage, the summoner makes a {@dc 14} Wisdom save. On a failed save, the summoner takes psychic damage equal to half the damage dealt to the manifestation.

trait.name: Late Bloomer
entries: The manifestation's recharge abilities start combat expended, and cannot be used the first round of combat.

trait.name: Aura of Lamentation
entries: A creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the manifestation that can see or hear it must make a {@dc 14} Intelligence saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage.

trait.name: Smoky Form
entries: The manifestation can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

action.name: Painful Reintegration {@recharge 5}
entries: The manifestation fuses with the summoner, destroying the manifestation. The summoner must make a {@dc 14} Charisma save. The summoner takes psychic damage equal to the remaining hit points of the manifestation when it was destroyed, or half as much on a successful save.

monster.name: Manifestation of Disgust

hp.special: half the hit point maximum of its summoner

languages: all languages known to its summoner

trait.name: Private Summons
entries: The manifestation has resistance to any damage dealt by any creature except for the summoner. Any other creature that damages the manifestation summons their own manifestation.

trait.name: Empathic Bond
entries: While the manifestation exists, the summoner is unable to feel disgust. The manifestation has full access to the thoughts, feelings, and memories of the summoner. When the manifestation takes damage, the summoner makes a {@dc 14} Wisdom save. On a failed save, the summoner takes psychic damage equal to half the damage dealt to the manifestation.

trait.name: Late Bloomer
entries: The manifestation's recharge abilities start combat expended, and cannot be used the first round of combat.

trait.name: Smoky Form
entries: The manifestation can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

action.name: Evoke Remorse
entries: The manifestation shows moments of the summoner's prejudice in the aims of breeding trust and remorse. The summoner must make a {@dc 14} Intelligence save or take (summoner's hit die) psychic damage. The manifestation gains hit points equal to half of the psychic damage dealt.

action.name: Painful Reintegration {@recharge 5}
entries: The manifestation fuses with the summoner, destroying the manifestation. The summoner must make a {@dc 14} Charisma save. The summoner takes psychic damage equal to the remaining hit points of the manifestation when it was destroyed, or half as much on a successful save.

monster.name: Manifestation of Surprise

hp.special: half the hit point maximum of its summoner

languages: all languages known to its summoner

trait.name: Private Summons
entries: The manifestation has resistance to any damage dealt by any creature except for the summoner. Any other creature that damages the manifestation summons their own manifestation.

trait.name: Empathic Bond
entries: While the manifestation exists, the summoner is unable to feel surprised. The summoner also has trouble gathering the emotional impetus to react properly; when the manifestation is formed and again at the start of each of the manifestation's turns, the summoner must make a {@dc 14} Wisdom save or be {@condition stunned} until the start of the manifestation's next turn. The manifestation has full access to the thoughts, feelings, and memories of the summoner.

trait.name: Impending Doom
entries: The manifestation loses the greater of 5 or half of its remaining hit points at the end of each of its turns.

trait.name: Smoky Form
entries: The manifestation can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

action.name: Evoke Anxiety
entries: The manifestation attempts to overwhelm the summoner with its most worrying troubles. The summoner must make a {@dc 14} Intelligence save or take (summoner's hit die) psychic damage. The manifestation gains hit points equal to the psychic damage dealt.

reaction.name: Sudden End
entries: As a reaction when the manifestation would be destroyed, the manifestation forces the summoner to make a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw. The summoner takes psychic damage equal to the summoner's level * the number of rounds the manifestation existed, or half as much damage on a successful save.

monster.name: Manifestation of Anticipation

hp.special: half the hit point maximum of its summoner

languages: all languages known to its summoner

trait.name: Private Summons
entries: The manifestation has resistance to any damage dealt by any creature except for the summoner. Any other creature that damages the manifestation summons their own manifestation.

trait.name: Empathic Bond
entries: While the manifestation exists, the summoner is unable to feel disgust. The manifestation has full access to the thoughts, feelings, and memories of the summoner. When the manifestation takes damage, the summoner makes a {@dc 14} Wisdom save. On a failed save, the summoner takes psychic damage equal to half the damage dealt to the manifestation.

trait.name: Unpredictable
entries: The manifestation has advantage on saving throws from the summoner's abilities, and the summoner's attacks against the manifestation have disadvantage.

trait.name: Smoky Form
entries: The manifestation can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

action.name: Double Whammy
entries: The manifestation uses emotional attrition, and then uses its evoke apathy ability.

action.name: Evoke Apathy
entries: The manifestation promotes a nihilistic philosophy and derides the futility of the summoner'a actions. The summoner must make a {@dc 14} Intelligence save or take (summoner's hit die) psychic damage. The manifestation gains hit points equal to the psychic damage dealt.

action.name: Emotional Attrition {@recharge 5}
entries: The manifestation assaults the summoner with a barrage of surprising stimuli. The summoner may make a {@dc 14} Charisma save. On a failed save, the summoner takes a stack of {@condition exhaustion} and has disadvantage on saving throws until the end of the summoner's next turn. On a successful save, the summoner takes (summoner's hit die) psychic damage instead. The manifestation gains hit points equal to half the psychic damage dealt.

trait.name: Indomitable (3/Day)
entries: Nezarin can reroll a saving throw it fails. he must use the new roll.

trait.name: Survivor
entries: Nezarin regains 10 hit points at the start of his turn if he has at least 1 hit point but fewer hit points than half his hit point maximum.

trait.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: Nezarin has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and magic can't put Nezarin to sleep.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Nezarin makes three weapon attacks.

action.name: Rapier
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

legendary.name: Weapon Attack
entries: Nezarin makes a weapon attack.

legendary.name: Command Ally
entries: Nezarin targets one ally it can see within 30 feet of it. if the target can see and hear Nezarin, the target can make one weapon attack as a reaction and gains advantage on the attack roll.

legendary.name: Frighten Foe (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Nezarin targets one enemy he can see within 30 feet of it. If the target can see and hear it, the target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the end of Nezarin's next turn.

Warlords are legendary battlefield commanders whose names are spoken with awe. After a string of decisive victories, a warlord could easily take on the role of monarch or general and attract followers willing to die for his or her banner.

trait.name: Reactive
entries: The giant can take one reaction on every turn in a combat.

trait.name: Vigilant
entries: The giant can't be surprised or flanked.

trait.name: Earth Glide
entries: The giant can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. While doing so, the giant doesn't disturb the material it moves through.

trait.name: Sure-Footed
entries: The giant has advantage on Strength and Dexterity saving throws made against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Damage Reduction
entries: The giant reduces incoming damage by 3. Damage from 6th level spell slots, legendary+ weapons, and attacks expending a mythic surge bypass this restriction.

trait.name: Peaceful
entries: When the giant would deal vitality damage, the giant deals no vitality damage instead. The creature hit must make a Constitution save ({@dc 5}+half the damage taken) or be {@condition stunned} until the end of their next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes four fist attacks. The giant can substitute two fist attacks for a grapple attack or a suplex.

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d4 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Harden
entries: The giant becomes as still and hardy as a statue. Until the start of its next turn, it gains a +5 to its AC, it uses Constitution or Strength saves (as determined by the DM) instead of Dexterity saves, and it has resistance to all types of damage. It can only use its rebuff reaction.

action.name: Suplex
entries: The giant smashes a {@condition grappled} creature into the ground, ending the grapple and knocking the target {@condition prone}. The target must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw. The creature takes 28{{@damage 4d10 + 6}} bludgeoning damage, or half as much on a successful save.

reaction.name: Rebuff (requires harden)
entries: The giant makes a fist attack against a creature who misses the giant with a melee attack.

reaction.name: Grab
entries: While underground, the giant makes a grapple attack against a creature that moves on the ground above it.

reaction.name: Dig
entries: When targeted by a ranged attack, the giant burrows underground.

reaction.name: Deflect
entries: The giant adds +5 AC to an attack that would hit it.

Extra pairs of arms magically orbit the bodies of the titanic, nearly forgotten artisans known as hundred-handed ones. These giants often dwell in remote mountains and seaside cliffs, where they carve their memories into the ancient stone, covering their territories with intricate reliefs and massive statues of bygone ages. Some linger near ancient temples and palaces, ruins they once raised to the gods or archons of old.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The giant's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Damage Reduction
entries: The giant reduces incoming damage by 3. Damage from 6th level spell slots, legendary+ weapons, and attacks expending a mythic surge bypass this restriction.

trait.name: Flame Aura
entries: At the start of each of the giant's turns, each creature within 5 feet of it takes 5 fire damage, and flammable objects in the aura that aren't being worn or carried ignite. A creature that touches the giant or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 fire damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes two chain attacks or hurls flame twice.

action.name: Chain
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage, plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Hurl Flame
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 7} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 5d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d4 + 7}) bludgeoning damage, plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) fire damage.

legendary.name: Rocket
entries: The giant flies up to 60 feet.

legendary.name: Shove
entries: The giant takes the shove action.

legendary.name: Pummel
entries: The giant uses its fist attack against a {@condition prone} target.

legendary.name: Roar (costs 2 actions)
entries: Each creature who can hear the giant must make a {@dc 15} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition frightened}. A creature can repeat the save at the end of each of its turns.
Master crafters and organized warriors, fire giants dwell among volcanoes, lava floes, and rocky mountains. They are ruthless militaristic brutes whose mastery of metalwork is legendary.

entries.name: Fire Forged
entries: Fire giant fortresses are built around and inside volcanoes or near magma-filled caverns. The blistering heat of their homes fuels the fire giants' forges, and causes the iron of their fortress walls to glow a comforting orange. In lands far removed from volcanic heat, fire giants mine coal to burn. Traditional smithies occupy places of honor in their demesnes, and the giants' stony fortresses constantly belch plumes of sooty smoke. In more remote outposts, fire giants burn wood to keep their forge fires lit, deforesting leagues of land in all directions.

Fire giants shun cold as much as their cousins the frost giants hate heat. They can adapt to cold environments with effort, though, keeping their hearth fires burning bright and wearing heavy woolen clothing and furs to stay warm.

entries.name: Martial Experts
entries: From birth, a fire giant is taught to embrace a legacy of war. At the cradle, its parents chant songs of battle. As children, fire giants play at war, hurling igneous rocks at one another across the banks of magma rivers. In later years, formal martial training becomes an integral part of life in the giants' fortresses and underground realms of smoke and ash.
The fire giants' songs are odes of battles lost and won, while their dances are martial formations of pounding feet that resound like smiths' hammers throughout their smoky halls.

Just as fire giants pass down their knowledge of crafting from generation to generation, their renowned fighting prowess comes not from wild fury but from endless discipline and training. Enemies make the mistake of underestimating fire giants based on their brutish manner, learning too late that these giants live for combat and can be shrewd tacticians.

entries.name: Feudal Lords
entries: Humanoids conquered in war become serfs to the fire giants. The serfs work the farms and fields on the outskirts of fire giant halls and fortresses, raising livestock and harvesting fields whose bounty is almost entirely tithed to the fire giant kings.

Fire giant crafters work through insight and experience rather than writing or arithmetic. Though most fire giants place little worth on such frivolousness, they sometimes keep slaves at court who are versed in such skills. Serfs not destined for court or the fields (especially dwarves) are taken to the fire giants' mountainous realms to mine ore and gemstones from deep within the earth.

Fire giants low in the ordning manage the mine tunnels and the slaves that toil there, few of which survive the difficult and dangerous work for long. Though fire giants are skilled in the engineering of mine tunnels and the gathering of ore, they place less importance on the safety of their slaves than on smelting and working the bounty those slaves produce.

entries.name: Skilled Artisans
entries: Fire giants have a fearsome reputation as soldiers and conquerors, and for their ability to burn, plunder, and destroy. Yet among the giants, fire giants produce the greatest crafters and artists. They excel at smelting and smith work, as they do at the engineering of metal and stone, and the quality of their artistry shows even in their implements of destruction and their weapons of war.

Fire giants strive to build the strongest fortresses and most potent siege weapons. They experiment with alloys to create the hardest armor, then forge the swords that can pierce it. Such work requires brawn and brains in equal measure, and fire giants high in the ordning tend to be the smartest and strongest of their kind.

entries.name: Giants
entries: Ancient empires once cast long shadows over a world that quaked beneath the giants' feet. In those lost days, these towering figures were dragon slayers, dreamers, crafters, and kings, but their kind fell from glory long ago. However, even divided among secluded clans scattered throughout the world, the giants maintain the customs and traditions of old.

entries.name: Old as Legend
entries: In remote regions of the world, the last remaining plinths, monoliths, and statues of the great giant empires bow their heads in desolate obscurity. Where once those empires sprawled across all lands, now the giants dwell in isolated tribes and clans.

Giants are almost as old as dragons, which were still young when the giants' heavy feet first shook the foundations of the world. As they spread across new lands, giants and dragons fought bitter generational wars that nearly brought both sides low. No living giant remembers what started the conflict, but myths and tales of their race's glorious dawn are still sung in their steadings and holdfasts, vilifying the primeval wyrms. Giants and dragons continue to harbor grudges against one another, and it is seldom that they will meet or occupy the same area without a fight.

entries.name: The Ordning
entries: Each of the main giant races-the cloud, fire, frost, hill, stone, and storm giants-are related by common elements of history, religion, and culture. They view one another as kindred, keeping any inherent animosity over territory and ambition to a minimum.

Giants belong to a caste structure called the ordning. Based on social class and highly organized, the ordning assigns a social rank to each giant. By understanding its place in the ordning, a giant knows which other giants are inferior or superior to it, since no two giants are equal. Each of the giant races analyzes a different combination of skills or qualities to determine the ordning. Giants make excelling in these qualities the purpose of their lives.

At the highest level of the ordning, the races of the giants are also ranked according to status. Storm giants are the highest in the ordning, followed by cloud giants, fire giants, frost giants, stone giants, hill giants, and finally giant kin such as fomorians, ettins, and ogres.

Regardless of a giant's rank among its own race, the chief of a hill giant tribe is inferior to the most common of stone giants. The lowest ranked giant of any type is superior to the highest ranked giant of an inferior type. It isn't considered evil to disrespect or even betray a giant of another type, merely rude.

entries.name: Giant Gods
entries: When the giants' ancient empires fell, Annam, father of all giants, forsook his children and the world. He swore never to look upon either again until the giants had returned to their glory and reclaimed their birthright as rulers of the world. As a result, giants pray not to Annam but to his divine children, along with a host of hero-deities and godly villains that make up the giants' pantheon.

Chief among these gods are the children of Annam, whose sons represent each type of giant: Stronmaus for storm giants, Memnor for cloud giants, Skoraeus Stonebones for stone giants, Thrym for frost giants, Surtur for fire giants, and Grolantor for hill giants. Not all giants automatically revere their kind's primary deity, however. Many good cloud giants refuse to worship the deceitful Memnor, and a storm giant dwelling in the icy mountains of the north might pay more homage to Thrym than Stronmaus. Other giants feel a stronger connection to Annam's daughters, who include Hiatea, the huntress and home warden; Iallanis, goddess of love and peace; and Diancastra, an impetuous and arrogant trickster.

Some giants abandon their own gods and fall prey to demon cults, paying homage to Baphomet or Kostchtchie. To worship them or any other non-giant deity is a great sin against the ordning, and almost certain to make a giant an outcast.
